blog.name: davidmann95
blog.title: Not Even 50% Of My TRUE Power
blog.description: Comics guy, writer guy, Superman guy

summary: With the success of Damian Wayne and Jon Kent, who else would you suggest getting a "Superchild" treatment? Maybe Lex? Wonder...
question: With the success of Damian Wayne and Jon Kent, who else would you suggest getting a "Superchild" treatment? Maybe Lex? Wonder Woman? Iron Man?
answer: I don’t know that it can be done again the same way. I guess maybe Spider-Man since there’s now a whole non-One More Day timeline that could be folded in via Renew Your Vows, but even that feels like a dicey proposition at this point. Otherwise - unless you did some awkward rapid-aging ala Wally’s kids or time-travel ala every third X-Man - you gotta introduce them as a baby and just wait for a few decades to pass until enough comic book time has passed that they’re walking and talking, like the Richards kids. Jon was the result of a very unique continuity clusterfuck with him as the kid of past versions of Lois and Clark who was ultimately merged into the ‘main’ timeline, in a way that he basically had to be because otherwise he would’ve had to hang out as a baby and toddler for 30 years and DC would never go for that, and he’s too big a shift to be slotted in as if he’s now always been there with a normal reboot. And Damian showing up as Bruce’s previously unknown offspring makes sense even without Son of the Demon, because no superhero gets his bone on more than the caped crusader, so that he had a little ninja kiddo just floating around out there without him knowing it is perfectly plausible. Those were unique circumstances, circumstances that weren’t even pleasant to go through in Jon’s case despite the quality of the end product, so I’d say it’ll remain justifiably rare.

I guess maybe Spider-Man since there’s now a whole non-One More Day timeline that could be folded in via Renew Your Vows, but even that feels like a dicey proposition at this point. Otherwise - unless you did some awkward rapid-aging ala Wally’s kids or time-travel ala every third X-Man - you gotta introduce them as a baby and just wait for a few decades to pass until enough comic book time has passed that they’re walking and talking, like the Richards kids. Jon was the result of a very unique continuity clusterfuck with him as the kid of past versions of Lois and Clark who was ultimately merged into the ‘main’ timeline, in a way that he basically had to be because otherwise he would’ve had to hang out as a baby and toddler for 30 years and DC would never go for that, and he’s too big a shift to be slotted in as if he’s now always been there with a normal reboot. And Damian showing up as Bruce’s previously unknown offspring makes sense even without Son of the Demon, because no superhero gets his bone on more than the caped crusader, so that he had a little ninja kiddo just floating around out there without him knowing it is perfectly plausible. Those were unique circumstances, circumstances that weren’t even pleasant to go through in Jon’s case despite the quality of the end product, so I’d say it’ll remain justifiably rare.

trail.content_raw: I don’t know that it can be done again the same way. I guess maybe Spider-Man since there’s now a whole non-One More Day timeline that could be folded in via Renew Your Vows, but even that feels like a dicey proposition at this point. Otherwise - unless you did some awkward rapid-aging ala Wally’s kids or time-travel ala every third X-Man - you gotta introduce them as a baby and just wait for a few decades to pass until enough comic book time has passed that they’re walking and talking, like the Richards kids. Jon was the result of a very unique continuity clusterfuck with him as the kid of past versions of Lois and Clark who was ultimately merged into the ‘main’ timeline, in a way that he basically had to be because otherwise he would’ve had to hang out as a baby and toddler for 30 years and DC would never go for that, and he’s too big a shift to be slotted in as if he’s now always been there with a normal reboot. And Damian showing up as Bruce’s previously unknown offspring makes sense even without Son of the Demon, because no superhero gets his bone on more than the caped crusader, so that he had a little ninja kiddo just floating around out there without him knowing it is perfectly plausible. Those were unique circumstances, circumstances that weren’t even pleasant to go through in Jon’s case despite the quality of the end product, so I’d say it’ll remain justifiably rare.
trail.content: I don’t know that it can be done again the same way. I guess maybe Spider-Man since there’s now a whole non-One More Day timeline that could be folded in via Renew Your Vows, but even that feels like a dicey proposition at this point. Otherwise - unless you did some awkward rapid-aging ala Wally’s kids or time-travel ala every third X-Man - you gotta introduce them as a baby and just wait for a few decades to pass until enough comic book time has passed that they’re walking and talking, like the Richards kids. Jon was the result of a very unique continuity clusterfuck with him as the kid of past versions of Lois and Clark who was ultimately merged into the ‘main’ timeline, in a way that he basically had to be because otherwise he would’ve had to hang out as a baby and toddler for 30 years and DC would never go for that, and he’s too big a shift to be slotted in as if he’s now always been there with a normal reboot. And Damian showing up as Bruce’s previously unknown offspring makes sense even without Son of the Demon, because no superhero gets his bone on more than the caped crusader, so that he had a little ninja kiddo just floating around out there without him knowing it is perfectly plausible. Those were unique circumstances, circumstances that weren’t even pleasant to go through in Jon’s case despite the quality of the end product, so I’d say it’ll remain justifiably rare.

summary: So let's get some seasonally appropriate discourse in here. Do fans of a certain generation tend to overromanticize the...
question: So let's get some seasonally appropriate discourse in here. Do fans of a certain generation tend to overromanticize the Spider-Marriage that others do... say, Hal Jordan as GL?
answer:
I mean, I like both of those things. 

Really, I see less people romanticizing it (not that there aren’t PLENTY - I like it by and large, but it was hardly transcendent the bulk of the time) than others demonizing it - there’s a particular toxic idea simmering among many that getting together forever with a g-g-girl would forever neuter and undo Pete as a relatable character, but having thought on it recently, I also find that a lot of anti-marriage-in-superhero-comics proponents tend to use the same arguments against ‘OP’ characters (It undercuts the drama! It makes things too easy, stories are about struggle!). I hardly believe the idea of a stable relationship is anethema to Shenanigans and Shit Going Wrong in everyday lives, and I think plenty overlook that the idea of a happy marriage can seem as impossibly aspirational to dorky lonely young’uns as swinging from a thread. And for this guy in particular, him as having One True Love is baked in among all the major modern mass-media adaptations, and there’s multiple teen spider-kids to pick up that end of his soap opera baggage anyway these days.

summary: Yo, Spidey's turning 56! Do you have anything to say about that? I'm trying to (hopefully) do an essay myself
question: Yo, Spidey's turning 56! Do you have anything to say about that? I'm trying to (hopefully) do an essay myself
answer: He’s still dope! Even aside from being great in general, lately he’s particularly been a beacon of hope regarding characters who have fallen out of favor getting a second chance. I don’t know that general audiences were ever more tired of a character than they were with Spider-Man circa 2014ish, and now people are hyped for him in Avengers sequels, his next solo movie, his animated feature, his video game, his comics…guy’s really come back swi…he’s truly on the upsw…he’s in a good place right now.
